questions.Q: Is there anything else you would like the Our Revolution MN Endorsements Committee to know about you?
questions.A: I graduated from high school in 2002 and headed to NYU in New York City to earn my Bachelor of Science degree in Social Studies Education, which I received in May 2006. I followed my heart back to Minnesota and ended up in La Crescent (in Houston County, where I grew up). I became heavily active in my local DFL Unit, Houston County, in 2007-2008. Starting as what was then called the Affirmative Action Officer. I subsequently was elected as a Director to the CD1 Executive Committee. Starting in July 2008 I worked for the DFL Coordinated Campaign as the paid organizer for Fillmore, Houston and Winona Counties, and I remained employed through the hand recounting of Senator Franken's race. In late summer 2009 I was elected Vice Chair of Houston County DFL. During the 2010 convention season I was elected Chair. I again joined the DFL Coordinated Campaign in 2010 as a staffer to organize in the 9.5 counties of southwest Minnesota and worked through the hand recounting in Governor Dayton's race. In February 2011 I ran for State Party Secretary and lost. In August of that year the previous Secretary resigned, I decided to run again, and I was elected State Party Secretary that September. April 2012 found me joining the staff of Minnesotans United for All Families as an organizer in Fillmore, Houston, and Winona Counties. It was grueling campaign and I was elated on election night when we made history in defeating an anti-LGBT constitutional amendment for the first time. I look forward to continue having the opportunity to share my experience with the DFL in organizing in Greater Minnesota. I headed to Saint Paul in early 2013 to work as a Page for the Minnesota House of Representatives, and was witness to that historic Legislative session as the right to marry was extended to all Minnesotans, along with so many other monumental steps that benefitted our state. I moved to Winona in the fall to organize Outreach for MNSure in all of southeast Minnesota, and did that until they decided to change up the program. And in Winona I have remained. I have spent most of my life here in Greater Minnesota, and cherish that opportunity to continue to reach out to DFLers outside of the Twin Cities. I know and recognize the DFL fell short in Greater MN in the 2016 election cycle and being a proud resident of Greater MN, it is hard for me to accept that the DFL had a hard time reaching out to and connecting with my own friends and family. This must change and I will work hard to ensure it does. It is my experience and perspective as a resident of Greater Minnesota that makes me different and if I am re-elected as State Secretary, I will continue to work hard to ensure the DFL is active in every community.

questions.Q: Do you support the current Super Delegate system? Why or Why Not?
questions.A: No. The current Super Delegate system does not appropriately represent the voices of the people. Super Delegates essentially maintain the establishment by providing an individual person a vote that is equivalent to thousands of citizens. As we saw in the 2016 elections, Super Delegates often vote contrary to the will of the people they represent. The Super Delegate system is inherently undemocratic.

questions.Q: Do you believe in presidential primary?
questions.A: Yes. I believe in OPEN presidential primaries.

questions.Q: How will you bring rural, independent Democrats back into the party?
questions.A: The DFL has lost critical votes across the state because we as a party have not been listening to the people. Rural Minnesotans have long seen these problems coming, and have tried to help party leaders and DFLers from the cities understand. It is essential that we start listening now. As Secretary, I plan to work with the newly established Technology Task Force and with leadership of local units to improve DFL communications in such a way that we are more connected state-wide than we have been in years.

questions.Q: How will you recruit new candidates to run for public office?
questions.A: This is not the primary job of State Party Secretary, but I will support the efforts of the local units themselves. I plan to ensure they have what they need to communicate with one another and share ideas across the entirety of the state. The more connected we are, the better capacity we have to learn from one another when it comes to recruiting and running DFL candidates.

questions.Q: What is the role of DFL Party officers in endorsing and supporting candidates?
questions.A: The State Executive Committee has a responsibility to support local units and remain neutral at all times until formal endorsement proceedings have been completed. Once a candidate is endorsed, it is essential that we rally behind that candidate and support them in every possible way we can to ensure DFL candidates are ELECTED. I've heard this story far too often--candidates are endorsed but then find themselves without solid support from the DFL in the lead up to election day. Once again, I feel like this problem could be improved by connecting the party better. Communication is one of the most important things an organization can foster within its ranks. Communication fosters the sharing of ideas, and in this case can help rally support for a DFL-endorsed candidate across the state.

questions.Q: How do you plan to win elections (ie. campaign political philosophy)?
questions.A: I'm a big believer that stories connect us as a people. I think we need to take our organizing back to the grassroots, where it has demonstrated the most effectiveness in years past. When we empower individuals to share their stories and spread the word about our values and the organizations and candidates that represent them, we will surely take back the state.

questions.Q: What is your vision for the future of the DFL Party regarding the independent grassroots organizations (ie Black Lives Matter, Our Revolution, TakeAction Minnesota)?
questions.A: I think the DFL Party would be missing out on a big opportunity (and I would even question our continued legitimacy) if we did not only embrace but actively work with grassroots organizations such as Our Revolution, Black Lives Matter, and Take Action. These organizations form as a result of shared stories and deep commitments to actively improving the state of Minnesota and the nation. In December, I myself helped to found a grassroots organization called Women & Advocates Minnesota. So I understand, perhaps more than other candidates, just how important the work of these organizations really is in uniting people around common values and goals.

questions.Q: What is your plan to raise money to support the DFL Party reforms and future campaigns?
questions.A: As Secretary, it is not within the scope of my position to lead fundraising efforts. That being said, I believe philanthropy is key for the success of a massive statewide organization such as the DFL--especially if we hope to take back the state in a big way in the 2018 elections. I think fundraising is also dependent largely on communications. If we are able to effectively connect across the state, local unit leaders can share what fundraising efforts are working well for their area and help others that may be having more difficulty.

questions.Q: Why are you running for office?
questions.A: I'm running for DFL Secretary because we cannot afford to continue to use decade-old communication methods in an ever evolving technological society. I want to upgrade and revitalize communications and help to connect DFLers across the state like never before.

questions.Q: What are your top three priorities once elected?
questions.A: I'm glad you asked. I have a 3-Point Plan that I will begin work on the moment I am elected as State Party Secretary: 1. Upgrade Communications. Transition the Yahoo Group (currently only utilized by 1/3rd of the members of the State Central Committee) to a more comprehensive community group tool that can integrate other platforms, allowing individuals and local units multiple communication options while also connecting them even more effectively to the whole of the DFL. 2. Educate. Launch an extensive education campaign for both new and experienced DFL leaders around current technology and communication methods, which will help them stay connected and be more effective in their positions. I envision both face-to-face education at caucuses, meetings, and conventions, as well as online learning modules on the DFL website. 3. Ensure Ongoing Quality. Put into place a permanent Quality Improvement (QI) team for communication within the party to constantly evaluate what is working, what isn't working, and develop & implement effective solutions as problems are discovered.

questions.Q: Why are you the best person to address these issues?
questions.A: The DFL Secretary is the party organizer in a literal sense, organizing and processing documents, as well as managing communications party-wide, but specifically within the State Central Committee. Most people who know me will tell you that I am a born organizer, and I intend to work tirelessly to make the DFL communicate better. I've done this professionally in my career as a pediatric nurse in a primary care clinic, and for two organizations: Our Revolution Minnesota and Women & Advocates Minnesota While the day to day operations of the State Party Secretary are essential to the functioning of the organization, I believe my particular drive and skill set equip me to take the role to a new level--improving DFL communications in such a way that will bind us strongly together and better equip us to achieve success in the months and years ahead.

questions.Q: How will you use your candidacy/elected official position to engage more citizens in the political process?
questions.A: As Secretary, I plan to ensure the DFL is as transparent and neutral as possible. I think the DFL's lack of transparency and neutrality is one of the primary reasons more democratic-voting Minnesotans are not involved in and supportive of the party. The same can be said of individuals who do not typically participate in any capacity in the political process. The DFL--like the GOP, and perhaps even more so--is viewed as simply an arm of the establishment and not as a truly representative body of the people. Improving communications is one way the DFL could counter these views, by proving that we are truly open, inclusive, transparent, and a collective voice of the people of Minnesota.

questions.Q: Describe your experiences and skill sets that will help you be effective in office.
questions.A: In my professional life, I served as a personnel security officer during my time in the military and was responsible for maintaining an entire brigade’s personnel security files, as well as overseeing completion of hundreds of security clearances prior to two deployments--a process that required meticulous organization and attention to detail. As a pediatrics nurse in a primary care clinic, I manage tasks and oversee our “in-basket”, pulling and opening 50 to 100+ electronic patient records on a daily basis, ensuring tasks are thoroughly completed in a timely manner. In my volunteer time, I’ve lead communications and internal operations for two organizations, including Our Revolution Minnesota. I am currently working as an organizer with Women & Advocates Minnesota--a new organization which I helped to found in early December. I manage the WANDA Slack channel (a communications application), the Google working documents of our five committees, draft and send out email blasts via MailChimp to our organization’s membership, manage and update a running membership list, and respond pleasantly and in a timely manner to direct messaging via email, Facebook, and through our website.

questions.Q: Citizens (people) before Corporations
questions.A: Always. Period. End of story. The people in this state and our nation have lost their power, and it is being even further drained and handed over to corporate billionaires by the current presidential administration. As Secretary, I will do everything in my power to shift the tides on this trend in Minnesota. By improving communication, we will amplify the voice of the people, connect them in new and innovative ways.

questions.Q: Voters over Donors
questions.A: I have always been a strong believer in the power of people over the power of money. The DFL is here to serve the people of Minnesota and not the corporations or wealthy democrats who may hope to sway our party's favor monetarily. As a member of the DFL State Executive Committee, I plan to hold others accountable for neutrality and integrity at all times. Money is an important part of the work that we do, but it absolutely cannot be prioritized over the voice of the people--who must always be our number one priority.

questions.Q: People, Planet and Peace before Profits
questions.A: As Secretary and a member of the State Executive Committee of the DFL, I will stand firm in my beliefs and vote accordingly. People, planet, and peace will always come first before profit. As the party becomes better connected with me as Secretary, DFLers will be empowered to stand more strongly together against elected officials, corporations, and legislation that puts people, planet, or peace at risk.

questions.Q: Dignity, Equity and Justice for All Persons
questions.A: Dignity, equity, and justice for all people should be the very foundation of the DFL, a future that we must strive for tirelessly. Now more than ever, we need to stand strongly in support of our most marginalized and raise up their voices. As Secretary, I will do everything in my power to ensure all people-- regardless of race, religion, gender, identity, sexual orientation, age, or socioeconomic status--have a fair and equal voice at the DFL table.

questions.Q: Why is an Our Revolution MN endorsement important to you?
questions.A: I have long considered myself a strong progressive. As a former leader of the organization in Communication/Technology, the Our Revolution MN endorsement would mean a great deal. I believe the progressive platform is the future of the democratic party nationally and the DFL here in Minnesota.

questions.Q: Which candidate did you support for president in the 2016 Minnesota caucuses 2016 and why?
questions.A: I caucused for Sen. Bernie Sanders and was selected as a delegate for the SD 60, CD5, and state conventions in 2016. I was a proud supporter of Sen. Sanders for president and believe wholeheartedly in his platform to this day. Sen. Sanders and I aligned most closely with regard to the following key issues: income inequality, money in politics, climate change, universal healthcare, and foreign policy. Since his loss to Hillary Clinton in the Democratic Primary, I have been heeding his call to continue the Revolution. My candidacy for DFL Secretary is part of my answer to that call.

questions.Q: Is there anything else you would like the Our Revolution MN Endorsements Committee to know about you?
questions.A: It is an honor to be considered for the Our Revolution Minnesota endorsement. I ask for your vote for this endorsement and on March 4th at the meeting of the State Central Committee. Thank you!

questions.Q: Do you support the current Super Delegate system? Why or Why Not?
questions.A: I do not support the current Super Delegate system. Currently the Super Delegate system has 15% of the vote which can make the difference in tight races, when the deciding factor of tight races should be who gets more votes from the regular people. The fact is that it sends a bad message to the voters. Basically it says that Democratic voters are not welcome unless they vote the way the establishment wants them to vote. The system does not speak to our values.

questions.Q: Do you believe in presidential primary?
questions.A: Yes I do we need to narrow down to one Democratic presidential candidate. Caucusing is confusing and by in large excludes many voters who may not understand how it works and don't have time to learn.

questions.Q: How will you bring rural, independent Democrats back into the party?
questions.A: During my campaign I have made sure to call all of Greater Minnesota SCC delegates first to understand what went wrong and to listen. I am the only candidate in my race to attend Congressional District meetings in Greater Minnesota. I listened to DFL Leaders in Morris (CD 7), Grand Rapids (CD 8) and had someone from my team drive to Mankato (CD 1) to speak on my behalf since it was the same day as CD 8's meeting. I showed up and that is half the battle with folks in Greater Minnesota. Showing up is what I plan to do as DFL State Treasurer. I plan on hosting Town Halls across the state and especially in Greater Minnesota to understand and listen to their concerns. Additionally as Treasurer I plan on supporting the Greater Minnesota DFL Party Unit Treasurers. I had a conversation with one party unit chair who was also Treasurer because no one wanted to do it after one mistakenly broke campaign finance law and received a huge fine. There needs to be people in Party leadership that are willing to show up in these communities and I have and I will. Finally we lost a lot of union/ labor voters this last election because they did not feel like we were the party for them. I am the only candidate out of all Party office races that is a union member. I also am on the Executive Board of AFSCME Council 5. I will say we need to connect with our union brothers and sisters much more than we have this past election to win back Greater Minnesota. There is no winning formula for Greater Minnesota without Unions.

questions.Q: How will you recruit new candidates to run for public office?
questions.A: I want to make this party more easily accessible. I had no idea how to join the SCC except someone told me who was already on the SCC. This means it is way too insider. Most people do not even know what the SCC even is! That is one example of why this Party needs to become more accessible and with more access comes more talent for people to run for public office. I also plan on making sure that candidates who are interested in running for public office are well informed on campaign finance rules especially their treasurer.

questions.Q: What is the role of DFL Party officers in endorsing and supporting candidates?
questions.A: I think everyone even in DFL Party leadership has a right to have their opinion and preferences in races. However they must not abuse their power to tip the scale for the candidate of their choice. It is a fine line to draw between preferring a candidate and supporting a candidate. As Party officers we must be objective and plan to help whichever candidate that gets the endorsement.

questions.Q: How do you plan to win elections (ie. campaign political philosophy)?
questions.A: I think the strategy has many essential factors to it. The first is picking a candidate that can win, someone who has the community ties and the grit to win. Secondly getting a team together of the right people who can make sure all the moving parts of a campaign are taken care of is essential. Third the party must provide robust data for the candidate to use for door knocking and phone banking. Also the Party should provide a thorough analysis of the district to the candidate by outlining the assets and challenges in winning the district. Fourth, campaigns need to be funded so we need to at least provide a baseline fund for every race with a DFL endorsed candidate, and give more money to swing districts. Also In-Kind contributions such as lawn signs, mailings and fliers are essential. Finally we need to get other organizations on board to connect the candidate with the community, for instance if there are a lot of Somali speakers in the district, we need to have some Somali organizations brought on board to help. To accomplish this we need to ensure these community organizations that we have their best interest at heart.

questions.Q: What is your vision for the future of the DFL Party regarding the independent grassroots organizations (ie Black Lives Matter, Our Revolution, TakeAction Minnesota)?
questions.A: We need to build trust with many of these organizations because a lot of them do not believe that the DFL represents them. The first step is to build trust and let them know we have their back and their best interest politically. However beyond that I think we need to bring people who are in those organizations into DFL Leadership as well. Organizations like BLM, TakeAction and OurRev all have different goals that the Party needs to speak to. We cannot afford to be watered down in our beliefs as a Party anymore. Too much is at stake to ignore these grassroots organizations and go at it alone.

questions.Q: What is your plan to raise money to support the DFL Party reforms and future campaigns?
questions.A: We need to harness the energy from the anger and disdain that the people have of the current disastrous presidential administration. Many people want to take action now and we need to make it easy for them to do that through donations. The big donors will not raise money to reform the DFL so that means we need to get many small or micro donations to help. Also community organizations and unions can play a huge role in this.

questions.Q: Why are you running for office?
questions.A: The Progressive comeback is coming and I want to do all that I can to make sure we win in 2018. There is a man as our president who thinks people like my family are rapists and drug dealers which has never solidified so much resolve to fight back in my life. I also want to make sure our Party speaks to the new generation of people and that we develop new leaders for the future. Our Party needs to prepare for the fast changes and huge shifts that are coming all over from globalism to climate change. I am running specifically for DFL State Treasurer because I oversee financial reports and explain finances to non-financial people often and I believe I can serve as the Party liaison to treasurers across the state.

questions.Q: What are your top three priorities once elected?
questions.A: My top priority will be to serve as a liaison and resource to Party treasurers across the state including campaigns. That will be my main role and the most critical part of the office of Treasurer. With this also I want to present our financial data and educate campaigns and treasurers on where we are standing politically. My second priority is to speak up for voices usually unheard or not at the table in Party leadership. I will be the first Latino to have the role of DFL Party State Treasurer. Now more than ever it is important that the communities that will be under attack must be spoken for and advocated for. My third priority is to show up and reach out. I plan to host Town Halls across the state listening in on why people feel the way they do about the election and our Party. I also want to reach out to communities that do no trust our Party and make sure they are brought in so that they can feel included.

questions.Q: Why are you the best person to address these issues?
questions.A: I am the best person for DFL State Treasurer because I have the quantitative background to understand financial reports and to communicate our Party's finances to people who are not financially savvy. I also am a very outgoing and energetic person who is willing to put in the hard work and long hours to meet people, connect people and build our party. I have the unrelenting work ethic to make sure our Party succeeds.

questions.Q: How will you use your candidacy/elected official position to engage more citizens in the political process?
questions.A: I plan to reach out to communities that are usually underrepresented in Party leadership. There is no reason that we show up to certain communities in October when the election is in November. We need to be there all of the time and build community ties that are deep and not seasonal, especially now more than ever is this necessary. I speak Spanish and will use this to connect to communities and I believe we need to make the party more language accessible for all. Showing up will be half the battle, connecting will be the other half.

questions.Q: Describe your experiences and skill sets that will help you be effective in office.
questions.A: I am currently the Housing Choice Voucher Program Analyst i.e. the analyst for the Section 8 Program of Minneapolis. We are the largest public housing authority in the state and I personally forecast, monitor, and oversee a $41 million budget that serves 5,500 low income families and around 17,000 people. I must be data driven, detail oriented, and have a clear understanding of our financial reports. If I make a mistake and over forecast our budget then we overspend and dip into much needed financial reserves. On the other hand, if I under forecast our budget then I leave millions of dollars on the table that could have housed families and HUD takes the money back. I have a critical, high pressure job and I still have the energy to do all that I do outside of work like union organizing, revitalizing the Latino caucus, etc. I have worked very hard to learn advanced statistics in my graduate program at Columbia University in New York City where I earned a Master's Degree in Political Science with a focus on International Economics. Besides my quantitative background, I also have the personality to be a leader of the Party. I am outgoing and high energy with a clean understanding of Minnesota and the political climate. I can adjust to many venues and groups of people. I will go above and beyond the requirements of the DFL State Treasurer's office.

questions.Q: Citizens (people) before Corporations
questions.A: I definitely believe in 'people over corporations' regardless of citizenship status. Corporations are job creators but I'm not going to be okay with compromising our principles as a party so that those jobs exist. Corporations need to be held accountable that is why I will be scrupulous in ensuring they do not break campaign finance law and donate to candidates.

questions.Q: Voters over Donors
questions.A: Number one I am not running a campaign to raise money, however as DFL State Treasurer I will have a unique role in overseeing the financial statements of the party. With that being said, I will ensure that all of our financials are abiding by campaign finance law. However, to go beyond that I will advocate that our financial position should not compromise our beliefs. That means encouraging smaller donations from many people as opposed to huge donations from a few that expect something in return.

questions.Q: People, Planet and Peace before Profits
questions.A: I have never worked in the private industry since I know most of the time it is profits and board rooms over people and employees. Our planet is in danger and we need to allocate party resources to environmentally active candidates to combat climate change.

questions.Q: Dignity, Equity and Justice for All Persons
questions.A: I truly have a conviction to this as I work every day working to more efficiently provide affordable housing to low income families. Additionally as a Chicano I know what it is like to be on the receiving end of racist remarks and sentiments and racial equity will be an essential issue to address in our generation. The US is getting browner and if we leave communities of color behind the US as a whole will decline.

questions.Q: Why is an Our Revolution MN endorsement important to you?
questions.A: I see Our Revolution as a movement that advances the ideals of economic justice and inclusion. Also it is an organization that is championing the issues important to my age group that I relate to. Our Revolution is gaining steam, notoriety and respect among Party leaders. I want to work to change the Party in ways I see Our Revolution also wants to see changed. I am friends with many people in Our Revolution and I am inspired by their energy and passion. Our Revolution is growing and I want to be a part of that.

questions.Q: Which candidate did you support for president in the 2016 Minnesota caucuses 2016 and why?
questions.A: To be honest I was working on the Ruben Vazquez campaign that day and I didn't want to take a side. My community was what mattered first since we were under attack on day one of Trump's announcement, so I wanted to do all I can to get Latinos in office. So I was going to vote blue regardless whoever won. I did not like the corporatism of Hillary supporters nor later did I like the 'Bernie or Bust' crowd that didn't see stopping Trump at all costs as a priority. I believe inequality is the greatest injustice of our time, and Bernie is speaking truth to those issues. However I also believe globalization is here to stay, I am a globalist and believe we as a world are getting more interconnected as technology improves. In the end I don't at all want to be defined by any one presidential candidate. However, I am reading 'Our Revolution' and 'The Speech' still.

questions.Q: Is there anything else you would like the Our Revolution MN Endorsements Committee to know about you?
questions.A: I have attended a few meetings and love the energy and the ideals. I think that Our Revolution is a movement of our time as millennials and I want to be a part of that movement from the inside of the DFL. If I am privileged to earn your endorsement I will always have a line of communication open to Our Revolution. I hope Our Revolution can get more involved in the SCC and even the UDF to make sure we are the future of the DFL. Together we can get a lot done and move this state even more progressive than before. We have a lot of work ahead of us! I would love to stop by and talk with people more or have a phone conversation as well. I apologize for being unavailable last time as I was moving into my new condo I bought. I truly believe we are going to make a progressive comeback! La lucha sigue juntos!

questions.Q: Do you support the current Super Delegate system? Why or Why Not?
questions.A: I think that the super delegate system is flawed; it allows the people at the top to continue making all the decisions. I would publically support any measure to get rid of the super delegate system, or bind super delegates to vote with their districts/states.

questions.Q: Do you believe in presidential primary?
questions.A: I think presidential primaries are the only way to be inclusive; making the presidential primary process be done through a caucus means a lot of voices are dropped because the day the caucus are held are not always times that work for everyone. Having a primary allows for all voices to be heard, and it doesn't force independents to declare a party if it's an open primary. I would only support a primary if it important.

questions.Q: How will you bring rural, independent Democrats back into the party?
questions.A: Organize them. Listen to their stories, and make their issues the center point of our messaging. Invest in the development of our volunteers, so that they can take the next level in their involvement in the party whether that be through being an delegate or running for office. We must center their needs, and work with them to create the changes that they want in their districts.

questions.Q: How will you recruit new candidates to run for public office?
questions.A: Conversation, and showing them the path to getting there. Teaching folks about the endorsing process, and giving them the necessary tools to go through the process, and most importantly investing in their leadership; coaching and asking them.

questions.Q: What is the role of DFL Party officers in endorsing and supporting candidates?
questions.A: To facilitate the conventions, and allow folks in their home districts to make the decision on whom should represent them, and not have DFL staff or leaders greatly influence the process

questions.Q: How do you plan to win elections (ie. campaign political philosophy)?
questions.A: I plan to create strong narratives that will resonate with the communities that we are organzing and give them the tools necessary to feel apart of the process during the elections, and after, and strengthen our base each year so that we have more of a strong voter base over time.

questions.Q: What is your vision for the future of the DFL Party regarding the independent grassroots organizations (ie Black Lives Matter, Our Revolution, TakeAction Minnesota)?
questions.A: As someone who worked for an independent group (TAMN) I think it's engaging in the issue base work that these groups do during and after elections cycle, and making sure that their bases are in line with ours, and making sure that we a present at the table of what they are doing. I would like to see the leaders of these groups leading the DFL, and driving the work that we do as a party.

questions.Q: What is your plan to raise money to support the DFL Party reforms and future campaigns?
questions.A: Money is important, but I think the most important thing is to raise the base, and the voter base. With that we can build a grassroots effort by having our people donate, and direct the work, and how we're spending the funds.

questions.Q: Why are you running for office?
questions.A: I'm running because I've been working on the campaign side of the DFL, and want to take the next step in my involvement, by being involved with the party. I believe that the relationships that I've built and am continuing to built will be helpful in building a stronger base to last use through what's to come.

questions.Q: What are your top three priorities once elected?
questions.A: 1) provide a support system for our treasurers supporting local units. Create material that they can use to make their work easier. 2) strengthen the base, and build something sustainable that lasts past election cycles. 3) center the stories of the most invisible people in the party, and meet them where they are at.

questions.Q: Why are you the best person to address these issues?
questions.A: I have experience doing this. I know and can distinguish the differences between organizing and mobilizing, and I have the skills of bringing people together.?

questions.Q: How will you use your candidacy/elected official position to engage more citizens in the political process?
questions.A: I will continue the work that I do now of supporting candidates, and their teams. I will invite the people you don't usually see at the table to the table. And work like groups like yours to engage your members, and supporters to step up to the plate and run.

questions.Q: Describe your experiences and skill sets that will help you be effective in office.
questions.A: Organizing people and money, relationship building, and listening.

questions.Q: Citizens (people) before Corporations
questions.A: We lose elections when we put the priorities of corporations over people. We must tell the stories of our people, and how their lives are effected. For instance, we know that big corporations don't want to pay their fair shares of taxes - we have to ensure that we a fighting to make sure that they are paying their fair share, because when they don't pay the middle class has to fill those gaps causing them to bring home smaller checks that cannot sustain their families.

questions.Q: Voters over Donors
questions.A: Big donors don't win elections. People do. Voters should always be our first priorities. We should never have to abstain from a vote, or not support initiatives because our donors don't want us. As a public servant, you work for the people and that is the bottom line.

questions.Q: People, Planet and Peace before Profits
questions.A: We only get one earth. We don't need bad trade deals, or oil pipelines going through our communities because it'll continue to deepen the pockets of big corporations. We need to live, and the generations that come after us deserve a place to live, and air to breath. We must fight against every bad deal, and make sure that we taking all necessary steps to making living green affordable. Like moving towards 100% clean energy gird, reducing the carbon footprint, and giving incentives for folks to have solar panels on their homes.

questions.Q: Dignity, Equity and Justice for All Persons
questions.A: To start, no human being is illegal. Trans folks deserve access to healthcare secure housing, and to not be attacked when going about their everyday lives. LGBT folks should not be discriminated against, and should be allowed to live with their partners and loved ones, and have a family just like everyone else. Seniors deserve to retire with dignity and respect, and that means that we aren't raising the retirement age, and putting absurd caps on social securities. Black, brown, and native folks deserve feeling safe in their communities, and not being afraid of their law enforcement. Our muslims brothers and sister should be allowed to openly practice their religions without being painted as terrorist. Black lives matter, trans lives matter, muslim lives matter, LGBT lives matter, latinx lives matter and women rights are humans rights.

questions.Q: Why is an Our Revolution MN endorsement important to you?
questions.A: This endorsement is important to me, because Our Revolution MN is a grassroots, people powered organization, and I want to make sure that I have organizations like this to keep my accountable, and remind me of our values - should I do stuff that goes against our community and the values we hold. I want to sure that I have the voice of the progressive wing behind me so when I'm pushing for our issues within the DFL party I have people to back me up.

questions.Q: Which candidate did you support for president in the 2016 Minnesota caucuses 2016 and why?
questions.A: None, I wasn't eligible to vote. But pre- Iowa caucus I worked for Martin O'Malley.
